newsitem.title: BULGARIA: BULGARIA DEPO RATES RISE IN ACTIVE TRADE.
newsitem.headline: BULGARIA DEPO RATES RISE IN ACTIVE TRADE.

text.p: Bulgaria's interbank deposit rates rose in brisk trade on Wednesday as demand for funds increased for settlement payments for T-bill auctions and foreign currency buying, dealers said.
"Activity is high due to rising demand for levs, which resulted in a slight rise in depo rates," a commercial bank dealer said.

Depo rates stood at 1.2-1.6 percent annually for periods between one day and a week, up from 1.00-1.50 percent on Tuesday. Interbank repo rates for periods to one month stood at 2.5-3 percent annually against 2.5-2.7 percent on Tuesday.
Banks sought levs to pay for 12 billion lev worth of three- and six-month T-bills which they bought on Monday and for foreign currency purchases for position adjustments and for final clients.
Supply of lev funds was large enough to meet demand as most banks still enjoy high lev liquidity.
The average annual interbank deposit rate was 2.13 percent on Tuesday, higher than 1.42 percent on Monday, a central bank official said.
A new central bank main lev interest rate of 5.59 percent annually took effect on Monday, up from 5.50 percent last week. -- Sofia Newsroom +359-2 91188
